title: Telcos prepare for 5G health backlash
text:
His comments come two weeks after TPG Telecom told the Federal Court it had encountered such serious community pushback on the rollout of its small cell 4G network, over health concerns, that it contributed to the company's decision to scrap the rollout entirely.

Greater visibility

TPG's network had been predominantly "small cell", meaning its mobile equipment was installed on a large number of existing infrastructure sites such as utility poles and roof tops, rather than on fewer, specially built towers that were not in the heart of the community. That made TPG much more visible to local residents, and more vulnerable to their opposition.

As 5G technology rolls out, bigger players such as Telstra and Optus will need a lot more small cell networks, potentially exposing them to the same community resistance experienced by TPG.

While other telcos downplayed the business risk, they nevertheless said they were taking it seriously. Optus said it was preparing to step up its efforts to ease concerns about the health impacts of 5G, as it moves ahead with its rollout.

Lambo Kanagaratnam, vice president of network deployment at Optus, said: "We always consult with the community when installing a small cell. Given heightened concerns around small cells and 5G we will be stepping up our community engagement processes." This would include letter drops inviting local residents to provide feedback on Optus' proposals.

There are no established health effects from the radio waves that the 5G network uses. — The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA)

Andrew Sheridan, Optus head of policy and public affairs, said Optus relied on "respected, independent scientific experts and organisations for our information about the safety of 5G and electromagnetic energy".

Advertisement

"One of these experts is The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA), the government’s primary authority on radiation protection and nuclear safety. Here’s what they have said: 'There are no established health effects from the radio waves that the 5G network uses'."

Most credible scientific and health bodies, including the World Health Organization, agree there is little evidence of health risks associated with mobile technology, but that has not prevented the emergence of a passionately anti-5G movement.

Their concerns include that 5G will operate on spectrum bands – the so-called 'millimetre wave' bands – that have a much a higher frequency than the bands used for 4G, supposedly moving them closer to the genuinely dangerous end of the electromagnetic spectrum, that includes x-rays and gamma rays.

A petition on Change.org makes the following dire claims: "Research shows that 5G millimetre wave radiation will make people sick, especially unborn children, young children, pregnant women, and individuals with chronic illness. The predicted adverse health effects include cancer, infertility, cataracts, headaches, neurological malfunction, cardiac irregularities, and insomnia, in much higher numbers and potency than that being experienced as a result of 4G by electro-hyper-sensitive people today."

A survey by Roy Morgan, published in August, found one in four Australians was concerned about the health impacts of 5G.

Mr Althaus said while “nothing would change the minds" of the hardcore sceptics, he hoped the majority of that 25 per cent of people who have concerns would be convinced by mainstream scientific research that shows no health risks linked to 5G.
description: Australian telecoms companies are preparing a charm offensive to appease growing community concerns that 5G technology will expose them to dangerous levels of radiation.
